response.answer_text: Its a difficult question, there is a lot of possible answers… but for practical reasons im gonna focus in my personal experience (What i’ve do and what i hear). And im not gonna say stuff like “Read more, prepare yourself, be a good seller” or stuff like that. Im going to show 3 practical examples: Be a broker of expensive stuff. Im not referring here just to things like Exotic Cars or Apartments with a view of central park. Im referring at any big transactions sell, for example, something dumb: Sell 10,000 office chairs. The path to do this is:A.Investigate about the big purchases of a company. B. Ask yourself ¿What the company complain about the actual supplier?C. Find a manufacturer of a similar or same product.D. Reach an agreement of costs or a commissioner scheme with the manufacturer. E. Try to fix the complain of the companyF. Introduce the new product with the pain solution for the company.G. Negotiate (Sell)H. Make the transaction I. Make moneyIf you are a broker you can settle a commission of 5% maybe (depend of the product) (1MUSD * .05 = 50,000)If you act like the manufacturer (This have some risks and maybe you are gonna need cash) you can make a gross profit of 10%–30% (1MUSD * .30 = 300,000)Some warnings about this:This is simple but not easy, its difficult to access to the info sometimes, and you gonna need some legal prep of course. The first transactions can be difficult, but im sure that if you try this at least for 6 months and you learn quickly, the next transactions come be easier.Develop a specific Skill. Maybe this is not the answer you are looking for, but maybe it fits here: The world its very complex with a lot of deferents needs. It can surprise you what hide jobs can be very well paid and nobody knows about it. For example, work in a tuna boat can give to you the chance of make $100,000 USD per year in a junior position (I think you need some prep for this job, but nothing compare with a university studies). Of course this is a high risky job and its not a walk in the park, but if the money is the only goal, try it out, you can make good money in this. (This is just an example, there are a lot of well paid jobs outside, just think about the jobs people don’t want develop the skill they want and apply. )Invest in crapy companies. This is not an answer for everyone but if you already have the skills, you can make a lot of money in this. One time i was talking with a friend that is an investor and he give me one advise: “If you have the chance of invest in a good startup or a crapy traditional company, invest the second one”… reasons: - The startup: it’s not gonna make money in the short term, it depends a lot of market perception, and if they do one thing wrong, it’s probably they fuckted up the entire company.- The crapy traditional: If the company isn’t making money (Or maybe yes but below their competence) but is still alive they have the potential to be a grower company again, you don’t need to start a new hole company, figure out what the problem is and solve it. Make some changes it sometimes can be easier and faster. Besides it can give to you a positive cashflow in the short and long term (that is better than paper profit).For all the options you are gonna need soft and hard skills, make sure you are developing the right ones. Im sure it pays, you just need to have focus and be disciplined.

Two rules: Start right now, now matter how young or old you are (time is an ally), and use the 8th wonder of the world: compounded interest. Start by saving 1% of your income, increase the sum to level where it's not an inconvenience and does not lower your current life quality too much. Everybody can save 1% and after realizing that, 2% becomes a possibility too, etc. I started this way and ended up saving about 50% of my income after realizing I can live without many things and small savings now can be ten or twenty times more in the future. That 4 EUR coffee could really cost you 80 EUR and after your thinking changes like this, you start spending to things you really need. My passive income (from compounded interest) became larger than my actual income first time almost 15 years ago. I did not start from exactly zero, since I had some savings left from business I did in late 80's and during the 90's, but compared to current wealth, that was peanuts.  How to get compounded interest? In many countries the yearly income is taxed every year, which may make things less easy. Where I life, mutual funds, ETFs that do not pay dividends and many other investments can be used for compounded interest, where the income increases your portfolio value without taxes and taxed are paid only after you sell your investments. The old golden rule for investments (from Intelligent Investor by Benjamin Graham, thick book but worth reading anyway) was something like 40% domestic stocks and 60% in bonds. Current situation is that there is really no such thing as a domestic stock (unless you just count the currency used) and bond yields are so low it's hard to beat the inflation without resorting to high yield bonds, which in turn have very strong correlation to stock market (albeit slightly beforehand). That means you'll have to figure out a portfolio that you can keep for years to come and pay attention to the costs associated with the investments you're using. If a fund is taking 3% from top, after 20 or 30 years you have made your banker richer than you are. At first you can't start using most of the investment types just because your monthly or quarterly (or whatever you decide) increases to the portfolio are too small to quality, so most probably your best bet is a mutual fund or an ETF if you can buy them costs that are low enough. My personal limit for transaction costs was 0,25% (whether buying or selling) and if the cost was larger than that, either my transaction sum was too low or the investment target was charging too much. You should aim for diversification, which is also hard when starting, but you can get there after some time. Do not pick too many investments, because the benefits from diversification do not increase after 5-7 different investments. And you can't stay up to date with too many investments. Also do not buy anything you don't fully understand. Either study the thing enough or invest in things you do understand. I've never put my money in something I don't fully understand. Do not aim for quick route to riches, because that means also larger losses and in the worst case, can wipe you out. Don't use leveraging unless you really, really understand what you are doing. Same goes for options and structured products offered by banks. In every investment try to figure out what might be the maximum loss you are willing to take and how much is that compared to your whole portfolio. My maximum loss in every trade is calculated to be 1% of my portfolio, and my opinion is that yours should not be higher than that either. Know when to bend the rules. My largest transaction was worth over 70 million euros during the May 6, 2010 Flash Crash. Not a single one, but as many as I could enter before the market was halted and transactions were cancelled. The flash crash is an example of the mathematics and statistics behind investments that I'll talk a bit later. At that time I had 4 computers following the stock markets, currencies, commodities etc. 24/7. Remember that a loss is a loss. Not selling something that turns out to be a bad investment when the loss had reached your personal limit you have in your personal plan can be costly. That way that 10% loss can turn into 90% loss. Not selling at a loss is kidding yourself, you already have the loss. Cut your losses and let your profits run. Try the calculator at Compound Interest Calculator for checking out different scenarios for your investment future. You can see that even small amounts can lead to large wealth with enough time - like I said, time is your ally and that is why you should start saving now, if you don't figure out where, save to your savings account or similar. Also worth mentioning is that debt is in most cases your enemy. Debt is reasonable when you can use the money for increasing your wealth faster than the costs associated with the debt (mainly interest) is decreasing it. I have never had debt, unless short term deficits in my current accounts (I was trading in 5 different currencies). Many things that people call investments are not. Houses for example are not, in the long term. They bind your wealth to a single investment target that has large costs associated with it (repairs, heating, taxes, you name it). The only hope is that the price of the house goes up (it may, but there are better investments out there), but remember that in most cases you actually make the profit or loss when you are buying something, not when selling (at that point you already have whatever outcome came from the investment selected). The reason behind this logic is that you can decide the price at which you are buying something, but the market decides the price you can sell at (you can select only the time, but not the price). Buy low, sell high. I use credit cards every day. But I pay the debt back just before I have to start paying for interest, which means I have an average of 45 days of interest free OPM (other peoples' money). I life in a rented apartment, because buying and selling one is costly, the prices are not reflecting real values (I'm still expecting mean reversal after the interest rates start to increase, which is not happening very soon, but eventually). And the cost of the apartment would be so high that the alternatives are making better income to pay the rent (which is really not the case, since I'm not paying any taxes for any of my investments anymore - I use my regular salary for monthly expenses). Rented apartment means also that I'm mobile in case the situation changes where I live, I could change the city or the country in a few weeks. Don't start living like a millionaire even after you become one. You may find out later that you lose what you worked so hard for. Stay working and if you're not happy with what you're doing, find a better workplace. Never settle. Maintain your lifestyle by not investing too much and after your portfolio reaches level that is significant enough, try to look for good portfolio manager and alternative ways to manage wealth (which means you may have the possibility to avoid taxes, or lower then significantly - and you have access to many investment types the regular Joe does not). Now I have 110 people taking care of things I had to do myself before, so I have a lot more free time to do things I love, but still not live lavishly. I still have goals, but not sacrificing my life to reach them.  And please remember: don't try too hard, because a good enough plan you follow is much better than a very good plan you don't follow. And you should have a plan of some sort, so you have already thought of things and can react more quickly when situations happen. At least the stock market is not following normal distribution, so most of the economical theory is wrong. If you are good at math, you can figure out better equations for calculating the real risk associated with individual investments and the portfolio. You should also know (or at least have a good guess) or be able to calculate the correlations between different investments you have. Finally, I'd like to quote John Maynard Keynes (or A. Gary Shilling, I don't know). "Markets can remain irrational a lot longer than you and I can remain solvent." Don't try to argue with the market. The prices may not reflect the true value of something at all times, but you don't get to buy at value and sell at a price, everything has only the bid and ask price and waiting for correction can cost you a lot - or in worst case everything. Good luck! I hope you find at least something of help in this answer.

8 tips to make lots of money  There is no recipe to become rich, but it is not a big secret either. Write down these tips and take advantage of the opportunities presented to you. It is safe to bet that more ink and paper have been spent on the subject of making more money than anything else. Who would have thought that basic things like food, transportation or a home would cost so much? We used to think of a millionaire as someone rich. Very soon that will be the level of poverty. So how do you get ahead and stay there with the costs increasing every day more? Surprisingly there is no secret to make lots of money. The problem is that people want it to be easy, like winning a lottery ticket, a magic formula so that everything fits in the right place to invest and become rich. Sorry to tell you this, but you must live in the real world, not in a fantasy. I share the way in which people usually earn money: 1. Start with nothing and grow in a rude neighborhood. Many successful people started with nothing and struggled every day of their lives to achieve it. Starbucks founder and CEO Howards Schultz grew not far from where I lived in Brooklyn. Competition and adversity make great leaders. 2. Do what you love and pray for a market for that. Steve Jobs said: "The only way to do a good job is to love what you do. If you have not yet found, keep looking. Do not settle "I was right, if you follow your passion and so do your customers, money will flow. 3. Follow the yellow road to Silicon Valley. The high tech industry has made a lot of money for many people, not just for the big executives. Why? Technology startups are the land of equity and opportunity. 4. Own your own business and live as a monk. Two-thirds of the millionaires work on their own. Most have small businesses with low budgets, they invest their money and, according to the book "The millionaire next door", they never received any kind of inheritance, do you really need a new car? 5. Take risks, make mistakes and trust your instincts. Many people take big risks, some smart, some silly things they should not take. Trust your instinct and act intelligently. You'll be wrong many times, but that's fine. No one won by going to safety. 6. Work as never before and make many sacrifices. It's not a question of getting enslaved, but take into account that Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer is a workaholic since she is in the office for about 90 hours a week. The same Elon Musk, has two companies and does not know how to delegate and let's not forget Steve Jobs when he had Apple and Pixar at the same time. 7. Create your own luck. They say that luck is when opportunity meets preparation. Even though I was very lucky, I never stopped looking for opportunities when I saw a pinch of possibility. My advice: let's tweet and go out to the real world to do networking. 8. Diversify, diversify, diversify. The idea of old age is so certain that it is not fun. I have an old friend, whose investment strategy has always been to put their money in as many different places as possible. It takes time and effort but the pay is incredible. Save your money, invest wisely and diversify. You can always call yourself a social networking entrepreneur or a CEO who generates all kinds of free content while the people of Facebook and Google become rich. The truth is that no one got anywhere doing what others did. It would be the same if you compare a lottery ticket and pray for a miracle.

Nicolas Cole Instagram There’s an old saying in business that instructs, “You don’t get paid what you deserve. You get paid what you negotiate.” I believe that wholeheartedly. Over the years, I’ve learned that no matter how hard you work, working hard has little correlation to how much you earn — or more importantly, what others around you believe you’re worth. Earning potential is related to one thing and one thing only: The value of what it is you do. Let me give you a few business examples: What is the value of someone who can scrub toilets?What is the value of someone who can neatly organize an office?What is the value of someone who can get people to sign up for your service?What is the value of someone who can provide assistance in a medical emergency?In society, we place dollar amounts on everyday tasks, and then offer payment to one another based on who can achieve the desired outcome — related back, of course, to supply and demand. Lots of people can scrub toilets. Not many people can perform emergency surgery. So, what does this mean for your own earning potential? How do you know if you’re being paid too little — and more importantly, how can you increase your value to the point where you are earning more than is considered “normal” for your responsibilities? Here’s how: 1. Do your research and learn what is most valuable about your role. Every industry has fairly established roles, and every role has its own list of responsibilities. If you want to earn more for yourself, do your homework and learn what it is about your role in particular that is valuable — and then look for all the different parties that are willing to pay for that role, and in what context. Let me give you an example. I studied creative writing in college. Do you know how many people told me studying creative writing would fast-track me to a minimum wage job? Not very many people make a decent living writing. So, I did my homework. I asked myself, “Who needs a good writer? What would my value potentially be to them?” Turns out, CEOs with powerful messages often struggle to tackle a blank page. I’ve built a company off my ability to write and tell personal stories. But that wouldn’t have happened, had I not done my homework. 2. Give up short-term raises for long-term jackpots. For four years, I didn’t make a cent off my writing. I did everything for free. If someone well-known needed a writer, I jumped at the opportunity. If a startup needed a copywriter, I took on the challenge. I wrote every day on Quora for free. I wrote guest blogs for free. And then once I had proven myself and my abilities, once I had 50,000 followers, once I had thousands of people on my email list, once I had been republished in every major publication on the Internet, it all happened on its own. This is the biggest piece of advice I have for anyone who wants to increase their earning potential. Forget the small raises. Forget the, “Hey so I’m going to need you to pay me for the extra hour I spent on this project.” Forget it all. Instead of asking for that hour paid, ask for an introduction to someone else. Ladder up your success to the next project, and the next project. Work with bigger and bigger people, for free. Master for craft. And before you know it, you will be at the top of the pyramid. 3. Don’t just tell people why they should pay you more. Show them. I am a huge advocate for personal branding. And what I mean when I say personal branding is representing yourself on the Internet in a way that speaks volumes about who you are and what you do. If you Google my name, my website is the number one search result. The second search result is my About page. In fact, the entire first three pages on Google, I own — with my website, my columns, podcast features, and my social media accounts. My social headers, I had designed. My photos, I update regularly. I write a new article somewhere, every single day. All of these things make it very, very easy for someone to look me up, sit back, and think, “Hmmm, I should work with this guy.” I get about 20 inbound leads per day via email, solely because of my personal brand. No ads. No PR. Nothing else. Which is why I balk at the people who talk and talk and talk about how great they are, meanwhile they’re practically invisible on the Internet. Everything they do is outdated. They don’t share any content that proves they walk the walk. From all the way over here, in front of my laptop, how am I supposed to know they’re someone worth working with? Stop telling. Start showing. And I don’t just mean entrepreneurs. If you are an employee of a company, you will get paid more if you have a strong personal brand. 4. “You can’t rationalize with the customer.” This is something I heard a mentor of mine say over and over again, and it continues to play in my head constantly. The moment you start trying to justify what it is you do and the value you provide by focusing on all the nitty-gritty things, you’ve lost. Sure, you might win their business in the end, but it’s not the win you’re going to want. Rationalizing with people only devalues what it is you do. You have to show them the vision. You have to get them to see emotional impact. This is what people do when I tell them what I charge as a writer. They say, “That’s absurd, I could hire a copywriter for $25 an hour on Craigslist. I pay someone five cents per word.” Yes. You absolutely could. And what you would get back is a bunch of words on a page, fulfilling your rationalized expectation. What you won’t get is the conviction, the voice, the tone you want representing you and everything you do. What you won’t get is someone emailing you after saying, “I was extremely impressed with the piece you just published today.” Rationalizing with the customer would be, in this example, focusing on how much they are paying per word or per piece. I don’t rationalize. I show them the real value I am providing, which always focuses on a desired outcome. 5. Ask. It’s amazing to me how many people complain about their current situation, but never ask for a different result. It’s a very, very rare thing for an employer or a client to wake up one morning, call you up (or bring you into their office), sit you down and say, “You know what, I’m going to pay you more.” It just doesn’t happen that way. Like I said at the start of this article: people don’t earn what they deserve, they earn what they negotiate. If you feel you deserve to be paid more, in whatever context you are working in, it’s your responsibility to ask. You have to bring it up with your employer. You have to bring it to the attention of your client. And most importantly, you have to be prepared for them to say, “No,” and to then explain what value you provide that warrants an increase in your earnings. This article originally appeared on Inc. Question: Do porn stars make a lot of money? It depends. The CNBC article quoted in another answer is three years old and only accounts for known performers who spend most or all of their time in and around the Southern California hub of the American porno industry. Since that time, porn has become more decentralized and more international, with private cam shows making up a sizable portion of the market. Most porn performers aren’t going to make their living from their film roles. Most are going to earn the money from: Personal appearancesPrivate showsAdult dancingEscortingPersonal giftsWhile they don’t have the cachet that a major Hollywood performer might have, there are places where an adult film performer can appear for a set fee and be paid a sizable sum. Additionally, all of the performers of consequence have their own websites and management who can book private shows for them with clients. How much they would be paid for those private appearances depends upon the client’s pocketbook and the manager’s negotiating skills. Stormy Daniels (of Donald Trump fame) has made an exceptional amount of money performing at various adult dancing venues around the United States. I you travel to “stripping destinations” like Las Vegas and Florida, you can often find major name porn performers being paid to perform shows at adult venues. Again, how much they earn depends upon their ability draw in customer and the negotiation ability of the people who make their bookings. Some adult film stars act as escorts. Since this is illegal and done discreetly, what they earn depends upon what they are able to charge and who they re able to collect. Some performers don’t care to do this; some do it more often than they make adult films. Since again it’s illegal in the United States, you are unlikely to get a true accounting of what is earned by the performers. Personal gifts are often given to performers by admirers. There are several sites online where a porn performers put a link to their Amazon or other sites “wish list”, with the apparent expectation that one or more of their “fans” will purchase the highlighted items for them. Since the items range in value from a few hundred to thousands of dollars (especially gift cards), the performers can easily earn as much as they would from performing just from personal “gratuities”. So it’s nearly impossible to say what adult film performers earn annually, questioner. It depends upon what they are willing to do and where they are willing to go.

The best way to start making money fast is to get some quick wins. Here are a few ideas to get you started: 1. Take Paid Surveys Websites like Survey Junkie will pay you a decent chunk of change for the low-maintenance, borderline mindless task of completing surveys. Companies want to understand consumers better, and one way they do that is by compensating survey-takers. Most surveys pay between $0.50 and $1.25, and many of them take less than 5 minutes to do. You can read our full Survey Junkie review for more info. Survey Junkie adds new surveys every day, which means you can make money faster than you think. 2. Deliver with Postmates Postmates’ slogan is simple: “Anything, anytime, anywhere. We get it.” As a delivery driver for Postmates, you’ll get paid to deliver things like groceries, take out, and even alcohol (which is a genius business idea, by the way). There are no fees or time commitments, so you have complete freedom over when you want to work. You’ll take home 100% of what you earn every time you complete a delivery, and you’ll be able to see an exact breakdown of how your commissions are calculated. 3. Get $10 from Swagbucks Swagbucks is another great survey site to make money fast. It’s similar to Survey Junkie, but there are also a few other ways you can earn money as a member (including a $10 bonus just for signing up). Other ways you can earn with Swagbucks outside of surveys: Cash back program for internet shopping (includes $10 bonus).Get paid for searching the web (includes $10 bonus)Watching videos (includes $10 bonus)4. Get a Free $300 Bonus as a New Lyft Driver If you’ve got some free time and don’t live in the middle of nowhere, becoming a Lyft driver can be a very lucrative side hustle that allows you make money fast. And right now, they’ve got a promotion going on where any new driver will instantly get a $300 bonus after completing their 100th ride. If you start now and hustle hard on the weekends, you can probably unlock that bonus within a few weeks of driving (and that’s in addition to your normal earnings). 5. Download the Nielsen App (and Collect $50) Have you heard of Nielsen, the company that tracks TV ratings? Turns out they collect data on a lot more than just TV. One area they’re really into is internet usage research. What does that mean for you? It means Nielsen will pay you $50 a year to keep their app on your favorite internet browsing device. The app itself collects statistics on your internet usage anonymously, so you never have to worry about any data being linked to you. And the best part is, the app takes up barely any space and doesn’t slow down your phone or tablet at all! Let's know something more about making money online.

By not losing it. Edit: Apologies for the curt answer. Here's something more rounded.  RiskMy personal view is that there is no such thing as one magic bullet that is "the most effective" asset class or vehicle for everyone. This is akin to asking "what is the most effective way to get home from work?" While the question seems simple, it depends on number of variables such as available options, traffic, risks etc.  It's the same thing for investing. Without knowing the situation you are in, it is really hard to answer what "the most effective way" is. At the most basic level, clarification around what your goal is and what your time horizon is in achieving this goal, and how important it is for you to achieve the goal, is required. In addition, it's necessary to know what kind of psychological biases you are influenced by because couple bad decisions can erase every last cent you earn over decades. This is the reason why I said "by not losing it". Step 1, which applies to everyone that wants to grow money, is making sure that whatever action they take, they have as close to 0% risk of ruin as they are comfortable.  This sounds obvious, but many smart people (Isaac Newton went broke investing in South Sea and Long Term Capital Management had more than one Nobel Laureates working for them) lose their entire life savings every year because they go for extra 1% yield without thinking about the risks they are taking. We are terrible at eyeballing risk. This is also why it's important that you have realistic expectations about what sort of returns are not possible without significant risks. (If you are OK with gambling away life savings to get max returns, that's OK too, as long as you are aware) Growing moneyI can point out that historically, (except for the last 10 years) equities have generally outperformed bonds, and that active managers, as a group, have underperformed the broad index, mostly due to fees and other frictional costs. Gold has been on a tear for the last 10 years by comparison and has outperformed a lot of other asset classes. But this doesn't tell you anything.  In investing, price you pay today matters more than what happened historically. if you invested at the peak of the dot com bubble, history would have told you that you should expect fantastic returns. Over the following 10 years, you would have made less than 0.  So, what is the "most effective way" to grow money? Pay as little as possible for  a future stream of cash flow. This works in any asset classes. Investing means putting money down for promise of money tomorrow. The "best" way, therefore, is to put as little of it down as possible.  Since "guaranteed" cash flow streams are well defined and trusted by the market, these instruments will usually not give you high enough returns to satisfy your goals. (If they do, hurray!) To get extra returns, you will usually have to go into asset classes where the stream is an estimate.  The goal then, is to find a class of investment where you feel that you can estimate this future stream better than anyone else out there. This "vehicle" shouldn't be defined in the traditional sense (by equity/bond/options, or by industry) - it should be specific situations. (are you good at timing corporate turnarounds? knowing when the market sentiment will turn on a specific few stocks? figuring out liquidation value of a hard to value asset?)  Since you are better at estimating these cashflows vs other people, you can recognize the bargains more easily vs others and take advantage of it.  It goes without saying, this requires significant amount of work. If you are not willing to put in the time, forget about everything I said and put truly long term savings (ones where you won't need them for 10-30 years) into low cost, broad market index (assuming you are not an accredited investor, in which case more options open up for you). Trying to earn extra few points in the market without doing the full back work is similar to stepping on the gas pedal to get home faster when you are drunk driving.     Hope that helped. Investing is where execution matters. If everything I said above sounds way too obvious and easy, let me assure you - implementing everything every time you make a decision will not be easy.

There is really only one tried and tested way to grow your wealth; spend less than you make and invest the surplus wisely. No matter how much you scale your income, you will never scale your wealth if you don’t get that right.  You get into the “perfect zone” when: Your income is going upYour spending habits are stagnant or going up with inflationYou are investing rightSounds too good to be true? Think about this. Most of us here are probably making 2x-10x more than we were at age 22, in our first job after university. We were probably just as happy now as then. We probably weren’t living off rice then either. However, over time, our wants can go up. That is what lifestyle inflation is all about. It is the biggest reason why you see business owners, lawyers, bankers and others making 300k, 500k or even over $1m and are broke. So the key is scaling both your income and your wealth at the same time. The easiest way to do that is: Get good at your job or business. That comes with experience. Then start your own business, not the other way aroundUse online to scale your income as a business owner or even freelancer. Or use online to get a second incomeDon’t let lifestyle inflation affect your finances. Just increase your spending in line with inflation or at most inflation +2% or inflation +3% if you are doing really well. That way you can gradually consume more but it is sustainable if you are earning more.Invest for the long-term. In low-cost and long-term orientated investmentsPlay the numbers game. It might take executing 100 ideas for 5 to monetizeIdeas don’t count. Execute does.Take calculated risksAlso be open-minded when taking risk. Many people “talk themselves out of opportunities”. I have lost count of the number of people that have said things like “I can’t scale online. Only face-to-face works in my industry”. Clearly nonsense but it is confirmation bias at work. The reason why focusing on the three elements of wealth is so powerful, is it all compounds. Simple example. Let’s say you have started your own business, after spending years getting good at your job. In the first few years you make 60k a year after tax. You invest 5k a year. You are comfortable but not setting the world on fire. Then you earn 200k after tax once your business really starts to catch dire, due to scaling online and playing the numbers game. However, you don’t increase your spending much. Maybe only too 60k. Now you have a 140k yearly surplus to invest - which will further compound your future income. If you just spend the extra 140k you have just scaled your income but not your wealth. I have lost count of the numbers of founders that have struggled for years, only to start making really good money, sometimes in low-cost cities and countries, who just waste the money. Then when business is down again 5–10 years later, they are broke, when they could have become millionaires if they would have fixed the roof when the sun was shining. Millions and billions of people around the world asks the same question over and over. And most of those people will keep asking the same question until eternity. Don't be like that. You do NOT need to sacrifice most of your waking hours. Choose a business you’ll love doing and work becomes play (but it’s more like a sport, so it can be intense).Work smarter not harder. Yes, you can use Autohotkey to automate a lot of computer-related tasks.Yes, simplify your business model. Once you have a proven/superior product, focus on 1. generating leads every week, 2. converting leads into paying customers, and 3. delivering the product. Can’t get simpler.Yes, you gotta earn it, but you can ALSO “steal” the work of others on the Web. Ethically, that is. Reverse engineer the successful landing pages or email marketing campaigns, etc. On the Web, you can see most of what your competitors are doing. Don’t hesitate to borrow from their playbook!There IS such a thing as a free lunch, since so much free information (a lot of PDF documents, templates, blueprints, etc.) is now available on the Web.Life IS fair. Furthermore, success in making money is almost about mathematics. It’s a numbers game (after you’ve created a good, proven, in-demand product).Okay, my turn to provide an answer. I am developing this artificial business intelligence (ABI) right now. But like a chess computer, it can only recommend the right move(s) for you if it knows what your situation is right now. You could have 100+ people provide the smartest answers to your question, yet it would not help because all these moves must be made in the right order. So my recommendation to you is to ask more questions like this one, but provide specific details about your situation. Smart people can then analyze properly and recommend exactly the few moves you need to make asap in order to embark on the journey to wealth!

You won’t be able to make “Lots of money”. But first a quick warning: always (always) be skeptical about people who tell you in details how they make $X in Y days and how you could do the same. Always think about the motivation behind it - and you’ll see that most of the time you are just being sold something or used for something. Just think about it: if they could make a lot of money fast - then, if it were still possible to do, why wouldn’t they be doing it themselves? Now back to “lots of money” and why you won’t be able to make it: It’s just too abstract to be meaningful. It’s really hard to get what you want if you really don’t quite know what you want. So, start with understanding of what “lots of money” means for you. Is it $2,000 of passive income per month?Is it one-off opportunity to make $50K - something that can work once and will be too hard to replicate?Is it $1M in your banking account by the age of 60? Or by 50? 40? 30?Are you talking about becoming a billionaire?Different “lots of money” call for completely different methods. For example, both a million and a billion can be considered “lots of money” by most. But the path to making a million is very different from the path to making a billion. After you decide HOW MUCH is “lots of money” for you and HOW FAST you want it, use the following framework to think about how to get it (I’ll keep lottery and gambling out of it).  You make money by generating value for somebody and, as a reward, you claim part of that value. If you work for a company, you generate the value for your employer, and you claim part of it as your paycheck. Your employer generates value for his/her clients and claims part of it as the company’s revenues which is used to pay salaries. So, to make a lot of money you need to be able to generate a lot of value for somebody. And generating a lot of value is super hard. Sorry, no shortcuts here. The stories about getting rich from doing nothing are usually written for gullible people by those who make money for writing those stories. From there you can start thinking about the business.  Observe people around you (whether it’s your bosses at work on your co-workers or your friends and family) and see what could make their life better, easier, more fun, etc. We all value those things so giving us more of them would be valuable for us. Bring lots of value at once to one client and claim a high reward (usually in B2B models) or lots of value over time to millions of clients (usually in B2C models) or anything in-between But what do people want and how do I give it to them faster, cheaper, better than others like me? Welcome to the club! We are all in the same boat on this one. I used to think how to deliver more value to my employer… and now, being my own employer myself, I’m thinking about how to deliver the most value to my clients, so I can claim part of it as a reward. I know this one is unpopular proposition that requires lots of time and effort, but this is the one that consistently works. Good luck!

THE ROADMAP TO $1,000,000 This is from the book, One Million in the Bank: How To Make $1,000,000 With Your Own Business, Even If You Have No Money Or Experience. Here’s the eight-step process I’ve discovered through trial and error, experience, and observation. Step 1: Really believe you can do it (or fake it ‘til you make it) and take action on that belief Don’t concentrate on your passions. Instead, focus on economics, logistics, and a business you can execute. Then, firmly make the decision to start a business. Nothing else matters until you get serious about putting $1,000,000 in the bank. Without that upfront commitment, you’ll do everything half-heartedly. With that commitment, though, you’ll find ways to make everything else happen. Step 2: Research your business Use the internet to research the kind of company you want to start. Go to your local SBDC (Small Business Development Center) or SCORE (formerly the Service Corps of Retired Executives) office and ask for help. Find other business owners outside of your market and ask them for advice. Find out everything you can before you waste your time and money learning the hard way. Keep in mind: · You do not need a new and innovative idea · Start with a profitable, tried and true business · Seek out all material available, including online resources and as many books and other materials as you can lay your hands on · Ask business owners about the type of business you are considering Step 3: Learn the business skills Many people go into business for themselves to leverage an industry-specific skill set. When I started my company, I simply transferred my experience from my former employer. It makes sense. But the technical skills are only half of the business and, frankly, the less important one. The critical half is being able to manage the business itself. You need to know how to manage your cash flow, how to hire and fire personnel, how to market, and such basics as it takes to run a business. To fill your skill gaps, go to SBDC, SCORE, and other sources of mentors and educational classes. Plus you should look for free advice to increase your skills in any other way possible. Step 4: Start writing a business plan You should be working on your plan from Day 1, but you don’t need to complete it before you begin acting on it. Regardless of how you use it or with whom you share it, write it for yourself first. It is a tool to help you get all your ideas out of your head and organized in black and white. Starting a business plan puts you in action and helps you solidify your thoughts. Step 5: Find the money If you’ve done your homework and have a solid plan, I promise you—the money’s out there. Start looking for contacts and potential investors as soon as you decide to start a business. You could also consider bootstrapping on your own. Whatever you do, look at different possible options, including a loan or selling equity in your business to investors. Money is everywhere. I’ve found investors for my other companies in such mundane places as elevators and even a waiting room at a car wash. Your vendors may front you the equipment, you could pre-sell memberships to your customers, or you could begin your business in a free space (like a fitness trainer teaching classes in a public park) and pay as you go. Step 6: Execute Most of the successful entrepreneurs I’ve met did something similar to the steps laid out above. Most of the business failures I’ve spoken to did little research, were ill-prepared, and sought advice from almost no one. The best approach is to have a solid plan thoroughly researched before you start and to set down all your operating procedures and policies (i.e., start an operating manual to help you consistently execute day-to-day operations). Step 7: Scale Consider having more locations and more products, leveraging the internet, franchising your company, or a combination of these. In the beginning, you may have to do it all, but as you scale up, always be working toward building a business in which you are not required for day-to-day operations. Strive to make it a system that anyone could step into and immediately be running the business. You don’t want to create yet another job for yourself. You want to create a business that can function without you. Step 8: Have an exit strategy Even if you don’t foresee yourself selling your business anytime soon, stay organized and keep good records as you build your company so you can easily sell it if you need to. Until then, keep it running and enjoy the profit. Keep in mind that many of these steps will naturally overlap, but all must be addressed. If you look at this list and say it’s too easy, you’d be right and wrong. Everyday businesses are not rocket science. It doesn’t take a Ph.D. in management to run a soccer retail store or even a multi-million-dollar company with multiple locations. That’s the great thing about running a small business—with the right prep work, just about anybody can do it.

The age old question :) Lot’s of great answers here in this thread. This is a question that I am currently in the process of answering for my self. I write about it on my blog which is a live case study of my journey to ‘earning lots of money’ or as I prefer to refer to it; ‘being financially independent so that i can live life on my terms’. You can check it and connect with me here IncomeObjective.com There are a few important things I have learnt on my journey so far which I will share with you to try and answer your question. First off earning lots of money is possible, but it’s not always easy. It will take time, effort, consistent action and the ability to accept the downs with the ups. Working on your mindset on daily basis is really helpful in achieving this and something that most people who are successful in this area likely do. I can not stress the importance of this. So many people think making money can be easy and effortless, and most of the people with that mindset tend to fail. I am not denying that there are people out there who do make money easy ans effortlessly, but that has only come after years of hard work, failures and real dedication. Sorry, not always the news people like to hear, but I don’t feel I would be being honest to just ignore this point. Secondly (and this is much better news!) success leaves clues. This is also super important. If you’re anything like me, when people say ‘you just need to create a product or service that people need but don’t have’ you groan in disappointment thinking how hard that is. Sound familiar?  Well don’t despair! Have you ever the saying ‘no need to reinvent the wheel’? What I am trying to get at is that there are a lot of people out there making a lot of money just copying what other people have done, and you can do this too. Find successful people who are making money in something that interests you and copy them. Obviously do not copy them exactly, but take their business model and their idea and put your own spin on. They are successful because the business model they are using works. So it can work for you too. For more information on this visit my blog and read posts such as ‘how to make money blogging’ ‘how to find a profitable niche market’ ‘digital Vs physical products’ and ‘how to build a website’ The great thing about the internet is that it has created money making opportunities in abundance and I would highly recommend this as a great place to start. Even if you don’t feel comfortable copying someone’s idea and putting you’re own twist on it at this stage, there are plenty of opportunities to sell other peoples products for them. Read my blog post ‘what is the easiest way to make money online?’ to find out more. Ultimately which ever path you chose to take in making money, you need to have the right mindset and the determination to do it. If it was that easy, everyone would be rich right? Take care and let me know how you’re getting on :)

The only way you can earn more money is by increasing the value (or perceived value) that you bring to the marketplace. Period. Everything that you do to earn more money will abide by this rule. If you negotiate a raise, you earn that raise because you helped your boss realize the value that you’re bringing to the company. If you sell more products it’s because you increased the value of those products or leveraged smart marketing tactics to increase the perceived value of those products. Anything and everything that you do to increase your money must start from a place of increasing your value to the marketplace. So how do you actually go about doing this? While there are 1,000,000 and 1 ways you can become more valuable, these are the 3 best that I’ve found after building a 7-figure business. Enjoy.  1. Increase Your Productivity (The Speed with Which You Provide Value) The first way that you can earn more money is by increasing your ability to get sh*t done and provide value at a faster speed. Think about it this way… Imagine there are two people who are equally skilled at their job as creative writers. The first writer can write 1,000 words in 60 minutes. The second writer can write 2,500 words in 60 minutes. Who do you think will be more highly paid? Who do you think will get promoted? Obviously, the writer who can get twice as much work done in the same amount of time (this is especially true if you’re a freelancer or entrepreneur). Therefore, one of the best ways to get paid more is to increase your output by leveraging proven productivity tactics. I’ve written extensively about productivity here on Quora I’ll summarize my best points here: Sleep 8 hours a nightWorkout for 30 minutes a dayEat a whole foods diet80/20 your tasksEliminate all distractionsWork on a 50 minute timer and take a 10 minute break after it’s overPlan your days the night beforeMeditate for at least 10 minutes a dayOutsource all low level workChange your work environment regularlyTake plenty of breaks and 2–3 days off a weekImplementing the above tips can help you increase your productivity by 50% or more. And once you are able to get more done in less time than your competitors or coworkers, you WILL start making more money. 2. Increase Your Skills (The Level of Value You Bring) Once you are able to get more done in less time, you’ll want to find ways that you can get more done while simultaneously increasing the quality of the work that you’re accomplishing. To do this, you will need to adhere to three simple principles. The Law of 1% and Intentional Practice: If you diligently work on your craft for only 1 hour a day and consciously IMPROVE by 1% each day you will be 365% better at your career/business in a year. That’s a HUGE leap.The Power of Education: In addition to improving your craft by 1% everyday, you must constantly seek out new and applicable knowledge that will help you get better at what you are doing. Read books, buy online courses, attend seminars. Do anything and everything you can to learn more about your skill set. If you learn one thing a month that improves how you work by 10% you’ve now added an additional 120% improvement on top of the existing 365%~The Power of Coaching: The best in the world ALL have coaches to help them identify their weaknesses and optimize their strengths. Whatever your current career path, you need a coach to help you go from good to great. I once hired a sales coach who helped me go from $8,000/month to more than $30,000/month in under a year. It just plain works.When you commit to the process, educate yourself massively on your chosen field, and hire coaches to help you identify and eliminate your weaknesses, you will quickly rise to the top of your field and be able to demand any price that you want. 3. Increase Your Status (The Perceived Value of Working with You) Have you ever watched Dr. Phil? He’s a marriage counselor, author, and TV personality with an estimated networth of about $400 million. An hour of counseling with Dr. Phil will run you… Oh, just a measly $40,000! Now let me ask you a question… The average marriage counselor charges between $75 and $150 an hour. That’s less than 10% of what it would cost you to work with Dr. Phil. But do you really think that Dr. Phil is 400x better than other marriage counselors? OF COURSE NOT! He might be good, but I promise he’s not that good. So how can he charge such an outrageous price? Simple… Because he’s increased his perceived status. (or value). And if you want to make more money, you must do the same thing. People want to work with high status people. Period. If you can increase your status by becoming a best selling author, driving a nicer car (e.g. Tai Lopez), setting public speaking engagements, and becoming a prolific creator on all major channels, then you can charge pretty much whatever you want. Not because you’re better than everyone else. But because the general public perceives your value to be greater than your competitors. You can start small here. Upgrade your wardrobe, create more content and get it published on major blogs, write a book on Amazon, do small things that make you seem more high status. Eventually, you will reach a point where you never have to look for money again and you’ll have more business and opportunities than you know what to do with falling right into your lap. Hope this helps Stay Grounded, Andrew Want my best stuff on quora? Click here to read my most popular quora answers about life, wealth and relationships with 9+ million views.

What is your personal financial strategy? If you ask this question a few years ago, surely someone will laugh at you: "Sleep on it." This is absolutely an unwise step. If you don't have a personal financial strategy, you'll never get rich. An average young person will earn about 40,000-50,000 USD per year and must spend 20,000-40,000 USD to pay student debt. However, there are also people who earn 7 times the amount above. When you realize this, you need a more serious attitude about money. However, don't focus too much on making money. This is a mistake that many of us often make. We think that money is the solution to everything. This is not right. The difference between people who earn a lot and those who earn less is great. And I think this difference expresses in some things the following:  1.Don't crave too much Everyone knows one thing - making money is more time consuming than spending money. You have to work thousands of hours to create a certain amount of money. After that, you spend them on a new car, a holiday break, a watch, or anything you crave. We all know this. However, you still spend money like water. This may be an old advice, but the easiest way to increase your income is not to spend all your money. This advice makes sense, because, for freedom, you need to reduce your needs. 2. Understand how the economy works When do interest rates often rise? When does it come down? What are bonds? What is inflation? What is the market cycle? What is debt? Why do they print money? There are many other questions, but you probably understand what the problem is. You don't have to be an economist, but you should also learn about economics, by reading books like Burton Malkiel's A Random Walk Down Wall Street of Burton Malkiel's . This is a great summary of how the economy works as well as the investment process. The problem is, this economic knowledge will help you avoid panic. "Oh no! The market collapsed! What should I do now?" Panic will not help you at all. 3. Limit personal debt Borrowing is not bad, but personal debt can ruin your entire fortune. If you want to start a business or develop a large real estate project, you will have to borrow money. However, borrowing money also needs wisdom. Like investment, it also has certain rules. However, one thing is for sure, never borrow money to buy a car, electronics, or anything that can wear out in value. If the loan involves the establishment and development of a company, real estate investment, or education, you must think carefully before doing so. Remember, borrowing money is not free. 4. Save as much as you can Your financial strategy may depend on your age, personality, location, education, experience, etc. People living in Manhattan can hardly afford an apartment. It's too expensive, so renting is a wiser choice. However, it would be more reasonable to buy a home in a city with low real estate prices. In that case, the rent will be much more expensive. Whatever you do, you need to make sure you have enough cash to invest when the opportunity arises. So how much is saving? This depends on you. Choose a number that you feel most comfortable with.  5. Short-term strategies We are long-term investors, not to make money one day or two day. But we also need a daily income to pay for bills. So what should we do? The answer is short-term strategy. Short-term financial strategies can be based on fostering skills and creating different sources of income. You should also invest in education, because the more skills you have, the more money you will earn. In addition, don't rely too much on a single salary. Instead, look for ways to generate income. This will minimize risks. If a source of your income disappears, you will still have other things. It is true that you need a lot of different sources of income, but before you do that, focus on the number of assets you have and improve your skills. The most important question you can ask yourself is: Can I create wealth? If the answer is no, you need to make it available, and consider it your top priority. Find out what successful people have done. You can also read books, research investors, experiment, talk to rich people, ...When you find a way to increase your income instead of spending it, that's when your property value increases.

For the amount of time I spend, I think I earn a pretty good amount of money re-skinning apps. Last year I was able to make over $15,000 working just 1 hour per week and this past January I was able to make $6,199 working just 2–3 hours per week. As you can see, you don’t need much of a time commitment to do this and there isn’t much technical knowledge you need either. Re-skinning apps is a pretty simple process. Basically, you purchase/create a template, change the graphics of the template, and then sell the app. The entire process will take between 1 and 3 hours depending on your experience. After having re-skinned apps for over a year now, I’ve found that the typical re-skinned app sells for between $100 and $300. However, I’ve had single re-skins that have sold for over $2,000! That’s a lot of money for an app that took just 1–2 hours to make! If re-skinning sounds like something you want to try, I would first recommend looking at Chupamobile. Chupamobile is a marketplace to buy app templates. They usually cost between $50 and $250. However, once you buy a template once, you can re-skin it an unlimited amount of times! After you decided on your first template, you’re going to need to re-skin the app. I’ve found that simplicity is the best when re-skinning apps. I typically just change the icon, colors, screenshots, text, and backgrounds of the app. I wouldn’t try to add features because this is time consuming and the return isn’t usually that great. After completing the re-skin, you’re almost finished with your first app! Now you just have to sell it on Flippa, a marketplace for buying and selling apps and websites. If this sounds like a good way to make money for you, you should definitely check out my YouTube Channel to see in-depth videos on how to re-skin apps efficiently. Also, join my Facebook Group so you can talk with other beginner re-skinners and learn from the experts too! I honestly believe somebody working hard at re-skinning apps can pull in six figures per year. It’ll take a little time to work up to this point, but its doable. Good luck making money!

The best way to earn lots of money and get rich is to invest your money! If you’re looking for a safe investment that generates good profits, consider investing your money in real estate. One of the benefits of investing your money in real estate is that there is no “one way fits all”! There are many ways to make a lot of money in real estate investing, and as a real estate investor, you can choose whichever investment strategies work best for you. So, here are best ways to make a lot of money and get rich from real estate investing: Single-Family Homes Single-family homes are the most common type of residential real estate investment properties. These investment properties consist of one unit which houses only one family, are built on a single lot, and are not attached to anyone else’s residence. Single-family homes are highly recommended to property investors – especially beginners. Why so? Investing in this type of investment properties means the real estate investor rents out the income property to long-term tenants. Thus, property investors can rely on single-family homes to generate positive cash flow in the form of monthly rent for the long-term. Multi-Family Homes These are another type of residential real estate investment properties. As their name states, multi-family homes consist of more than one unit to house more than one family. They range between anything from duplexes to 32-units apartment complexes! Similar to single-family homes, property investors in multi-family homes rent out investment properties to long-term tenants. However, investing in these properties secures property investors an even higher positive cash flow and return on investment since multi-family homes contain more residential units, meaning more tenants paying monthly rent. Related: Best Long Term Investments: Single-Family and Multi-Family Homes Airbnb Rentals Airbnb is an online platform that allows a real estate investor to rent out a residential income property for the short-term (normally less than 6 months). Renting out through Airbnb has become one of the best and most popular real estate investment strategies to make a lot of money in real estate investing. Airbnb rental has proven to be a very profitable investment strategy and, depending on the location of the income property, can even yield a higher return on investment than traditional residential rentals. Related: Real Estate Investing: Traditional vs. Airbnb Investments Commercial Real Estate As previously mentioned, there are many investment strategies in the world of real estate investing. Investing in commercial real estate means the real estate investor rents out an investment property to businesses (not residents). Obviously, since business generally generate more than individuals, commercial real estate investment properties yields a higher income and return on investment. Wholesaling You can make a lot of money and get rich with real estate investing without property ownership through wholesaling. Basically, a wholesaler works as a middleman between buyers and sellers in a real estate transaction. All the real estate investor has to do is find a seller, assign an investment property to a contract, and sells the contract to an end-buyer and walks away with a portion of profits made. Real estate wholesaling is one of the best ways to passively make money in real estate. Real Estate Investment Trusts This is another way to passively make money without property ownership! With this investment strategy, a real estate investor buys shares of a REIT that invests in multiple investment projects. Forget about the hassle of becoming a landlord, dealing with tenants, and collecting rent! Investing in REITs not only provides a real estate investor with passive income, but also a diversified investment portfolio! As you can see, making a lot of money and getting rich with real estate is actually not that difficult! However, you should keep in mind that although there are numerous investment strategies to choose from, what works for one real estate investor doesn’t necessarily work for another. Continue reading in Mashvisor’s blog to learn more about all aspects of real estate investing! Hope this helps :)

THERE ARE DIFFERENT WAYS OF MAKING MONEY ESPECIALLY ONLINE. (1) FOREX- The forex market has now opened has now opened up to just about anyone with an internet-connected device and a small deposit to use as margin. To make lots of money, do not make money your goal. The statement above might seem paradoxical but there is logic behind this. Let's look at two people: call them Bill and Elon. Imagine that Bill is the world's richest man and a billionaire who founded a fictional company called Microsoft and that Elon is also a billionaire who founded companies with cool names such as PayPal, SpaceX, Tesla, etc. They both have goals in their lives. Elon's is to make a multiplanetary human race and strike a path of solar energy in human industrial uses. Bill's is to build a system to make our everyday lives easier.  Now that we have our character backgrounds, let's move onto the paradoxical statement To make lots of money, do not make money your goal. Let us look at Elon because I know him better than Bill. If money was what Elon wanted, then he would have stopped after he sold PayPal for over 1 billion dollars, earning him over 200 million dollars. He was already a multimillionaire. He didn't need more money. But he didn't stop there because that wasn't his goal. His goal was to make a multiplanetary human race and sustainable environment and in doing so with he acquired billions of dollars from SpaceX and Tesla. There will be wealthy people who does not provide support to the statement above. However, that is the statement I believe in and I hope more people would believe in too. If you are going to be rich, at least do it for a noble cause.

The definition of 'lots' is different for different people.   If you really want to be Bill-Gates-Rich, the only sure way is to inherit from someone who is already that rich.  Bill Gates got rich by being very, very good but also by being in the right place at the right time.  When he started Microsoft, it was not at all obvious that personal computers would become so big.  So you have to be one of a handful of the best people in the world, in a business that's not too crowded with competitors, and that grows phenomenally.  Good luck. Of course, the best in the world can get rich in many fields.  I think Gary Kasparov got rich as a chess player.  But in most countries, even the national chess champion needs a day job.  So - duh! -  in any field almost everyone fails to be 'best.'   Ask how well someone average or a bit above average does in a field. If a medical doctor's income (100,000+ $US/year) satisfies your definition of 'lots of money,' then you need to become good at something that most other people either can't do or don't really try to do.  In the US, the first challenge is to get into medical school.  Odds are not good, even if you are a very good undergraduate student.  It's much easier to get into law school.  But the distribution of incomes is pretty broad for lawyers.  The best make a lot of money but there are also many lawyers who struggle. In most fields 'Research PhD' is a pretty small pool.  Average researchers in physics, chemistry, medicine, and many other fields do well.  But funding goes up and down and there are some years where new PhDs don't find jobs.   So, besides studying the right subject matter, you also need to become an expert on where the jobs are and what other kinds of job you might do if Plan A doesn't work out.  And studying both the subject and the job possibilities has to continue for your whole working life. Sorry, no path is easy.

TEACH. You’re probably thinking: “There’s no way that I’m gonna do that. Have you seen how little teachers earn? No way!” Let me, very briefly, introduce you to someone named Michelle Phan…  You’re probably thinking that she’s just another entrepreneur who parlayed her wealth in one area to wealth in another, and if that’s what you’re thinking, then you’re mistaken. Michelle Phan was actually a Fine Arts student, that happened to casually be interested in makeup application. She interacted with her readers on Xanga (remember that blogging platform?) and answered their questions about makeup. Eventually, she found it better to take those FAQs and turn them into live video content on Youtube. Mind you, she was not a professional makeup artist; just someone who had a bit of knowledge to share. The reason why I like Michelle’s story is specifically because she demonstrates that something serendipitous (like being at the right place, at the right time) can turn into an intentional business. When she started creating demonstrative content on Youtube, there was no Adsense partner programme, and content creators were not receiving monetary compensation for their contributions—however, when she realized that her content was bringing in money, she got serious and earned herself her first $1 million in annual revenue, way back in 2013 (or so). The rest of her story has been documented all over the web for your further reading… We are miles away from the years of being “the only one” doing something on Youtube, or “the only one” creating a certain type of content on any platform —nowadays, everyone is vying for everyone’s limited attention, making the environment a little hostile to new content. However, It’s in this exact “hostile” environment where valuable content flourishes! No matter which platform is the most popular or what the pop-culture trends are, people will still be curious about new information/techniques or facts. If you are disciplined enough to create your own course, dedicated enough to put some money (for marketing) behind it, and committed enough to not quit your day job (haha); you could make some serious bank! You don’t have to even be a PRO, because to be honest, if people wanted to learn from professionals, they wouldn’t be on Google. I’m an avid student, and after starting various businesses from a young age, I think it’s important to learn valuable lessons and then pass those lessons on to others, so that they can innovate even faster. With that being said, I don’t think that teaching will ever be out of style. If you are really serious about making money, then I’ll say it again: TEACH!

1. Master the meeting The average pay bump from a promotion is about 7%, though it can be even more once you’re a manager, according to Mercer. But how do you get one? “The meeting room is where we exert leadership and develop credibility,” says corporate trainer Dana Brownlee of Professionalism Matters. Don’t dominate—nudge the group toward concrete goals. If someone can’t let go of a point, try saying, “Good idea! I’m writing it down.” You’ve now freed a room of grateful co-workers to move on. 2. Lend a hand at work Research by Adam Grant at the Wharton School has shown that successful people do more favors at work, but don’t be afraid to ask for tiny favors too. We may actually feel more warmly toward people after lending them a hand—our brains figure we must have done so because we like that person. It’s been called the Benjamin Franklin effect: The Founding Father recalled winning over a legislative rival after borrowing a book from him. “Our attitudes often follow our behavior instead of vice versa,” says David McRaney, who writes about such psychological quirks in his book You Are Now Less Dumb. 3. Learn a language It’s easier than ever to dip a toe into languages with free tools like Duolingo, a site and app that make learning like a game. If you then want to ramp things up, real-world classes run about $300 for 20 hours of instruction. Invest your time and money wisely: The payoff is in less commonly studied languages. A Wharton/LECG Europe study found that speaking German translated into a higher wage premium than for second languages overall. Ambitious? There’s a big market for Mandarin. 4. Get techy Computer-science grads earn $700,000 over the average B.A. holder in a career, but those with English and psych degrees aren’t out of luck: There are ways to use technology smarter—and get recognized for it—at all levels. For example, if there’s any need to quantify your business’s activity, being the office Excel guru makes you valuable. Two skills to focus on: building charts (great for presentations) and pivot tables (to summarize lots of data). The ExcelIsFun YouTube channel is loaded with lessons. Want to compete with true techies? Codecademy - learn to code, interactively, for free can get you started for free learning code for building websites. Expertise in Ruby on Rails—certification testing is $150—snags an average salary of $110,000, says data crunched by Quartz. If all this sounds like too much work, at least Google better. Seriously. Say, for example, you need stats about a product’s market share: Use “OR” (in caps) to Google for different words that might capture the same thing (like “percent” and “proportion”). And check the image search results: The data you need may be in a chart someone has posted. Go to Google’s help center for more power tips. 5. Write better A clear, unfussy writing style will get your ideas heard at work. (HR pros ranked writing second, behind only computer aptitude, among skills applicants most often lacked.) Harvard professor Steven Pinker, author of the new book The Sense of Style, gave us these tips for better writing: Avoid fancy words you don’t need or understand. “Fulsome” (as in “fulsome praise”) does not mean full; it means insincere. If you use hoity-toity words to sound posh, you will look pompous and may say the opposite of what you mean. Cut unnecessary words. John Kerry once said, “The President is desirous of trying to see how we can make our efforts in order to find a way to facilitate.” What he meant was, “The President wants to help.” Much better. Revise. And better still, show it to someone. What’s clear to you may not be clear to someone else. 6. Learn social savvy If you run a business or work in marketing, social media like Twitter seem like a great way to get your message out. But remember that users have zero interest in following companies that clutter their feed with ads. Use social to establish your expertise or spark ideas; then when people are in the market for what you sell, they’ll remember you. Hannah Morgan, co-author of Social Networking for Business Success, explains that a good tweet is self-contained and has a discrete piece of information worth sharing. What works well is language like, “Baking cookies? Add eggs one at a time so you can mix in evenly. For more tips check out our Baking 101 guide.” Then add a link. A less effective tweet is something like, “We’re having a sale on tins of our delicious chocolate chip cookies. $19.99 all day Friday” because it reads like an advertisement and is therefore is unlikely to be shared. 7. Take back your workday If you get paid a flat salary, turning a 10-hour day into nine more-productive hours is like giving yourself an 11% hourly raise. Try three key moves from former Fidelity president Bob Pozen, author of Extreme Productivity: First, handle each email just once. Reply, file, or trash—don’t come back to it later. Second, hide that extra chair; you’ll discourage chatty co-workers from lingering. Finally, you might want to consider timing your breaks, since research shows your brain loses focus on a task after about 90 minutes. 8. Sell yourself “Ten years ago job seekers would write a full-page cover letter,” says executive résumé writer Wendy Enelow. A better approach now is an email designed to cut through the electronic clutter. Use the subject line to note your key selling points. Instead of “Director of sales position,” write “Director of Sales—10 Years of Exceeding Sales Quotas—MBA.” In the body of the email, spotlight a major accomplishment. Follow up with three big career wins in bullet points. 9. Learn to DIY Some jobs always require a professional but, with a little prep, tasks like painting a room or replacing your car’s air filters can be a piece of cake—and save you a solid amount of money. A painting pro, for example, could easily charge $1,600 for a big job, vs. up to $400 in materials on your own. Rich O’Neil of Masterwork Painting & Restoration in Woburn, Mass., explains that to get professional results you must dust surfaces and tape up edges and moldings you don’t want painted. Painting should go in two types of strokes: First apply a thin layer for coverage. Then paint over it to even and smooth. You can replace your car’s air filters yourself every 12,000 miles on newer cars. You’ll save about $50 in labor costs, says Mike Forsythe of Haynes, an auto-repair guidebook publisher, and pay 25% less for the filter by getting it at a parts store. To change an engine filter, check the housing in the engine compartment; in most cars there’s a cover you can unlatch with your fingers. You’ll typically find the cabin filter inside the car, behind the glove box. 10. Get organized Everyone hates paying a late fee just because of a forgotten reminder to pay a bill on time. And few tasks are as irritating as foraging for receipts from months and months ago. The key to never losing track of important papers is to keep just one bin and make sure to empty your pockets and purse into it every night. Then set a regular date on your calendar to empty the bin and organize the receipts. “If you wait too long, you may not even remember your purchase,” says professional organizer Andrew Mellen. If you find it hard to even check your calendar on a routine basis, pair a daily check with your morning coffee—or any other routine you already have. Good luck!

Secret of money making lies in delivering value.  The sole driver for making money (other than inheritance) is making lives of people simpler and easier. The more easier you make the lives of people, the more time you save of people, the more you make lives of people comfortable, the more you are going to earn. Let’s see some top examples- Amazon Inc. - It started from books initially now delivers A to Z items. What it did for people? It simply made millions of items available at one place and provide convenience of sitting at home and requesting products with few clicks. Facebook Inc. - Before facebook and other social networking sites, a news or simply an idea took a lot of time to travel from one place to another and till then people became aware of the problem, it is already widespread. What if corona virus outbreak occurred in pre-internet era? Mind-boggling question. If you think of an idea, you can directly communicate it to your friend. It is like telepathy. It made life easier. Microsoft Inc. - Microsoft created Microsoft Office which now dominates almost all offices of the country with millions of active users daily. Microsoft office helped us with presentations, spreadsheets, word document management, etc. thereby delivering easier ways to manage mega data. In short, it made our life easier. You take any company who earns money. The important question is, how did it make lives simpler? In fact, people who are earning money around you are earning because of the same reason- Teacher- Teacher is making life simpler and thereby adding value to the lives of student by bringing ease to the subject and increase comfort levels.Professionals- Years invested by professionals like CA, CS, Lawyers, etc invested their years of life in learning the skill to make lives of people easier. Time efficiency is the key factor here. The faster you deliver (without compromising quality), the more you’re paid.Chef- Nobody is going to hotels currently, so chill. Chef creates the recipes, menus, and does other managerial tasks. In short, it indirectly helps people to have a better experience at hotels. Making money is directly proportional to quality of value delivered. In itself, money means something in return for delivering value. Isn’t this a simple concept? Are we striving to make money or delivering value? Thank-you for reading.
